name: Private Kowalski

topics.response_text: You here to pay your respects, too?

topics.topic_text: You're a little bitch and your brother was, too.

topics.response_text: It commemorates the Battle of Hoover Dam. The rangers lured the best of Caesar's Legion into Boulder City, then blew the whole town up.

topics.topic_text: My apologies. It was rude and disrespectful of me to do that.
topics.response_text: [SUCCEEDED] All right, apology accepted. Don't let it happen again.
Camp McCarran, but I'm on leave at the moment - heading back to California to see my folks.
Just get the fuck away from here, already.

conversation.response_text: Oh, that's it. Your ass is mine!

description:
Private Kowalski is a 28 year-old Caucasian Male.

Private Kowalski is an NCR private encountered at the Boulder City Memorial in 2281. He is a somber and contemplative soldier, taking a moment of respite from his journey home to pay respects to his fallen brother.

Private Kowalski's Personality: Private Kowalski is loyal to the NCR and deeply values family bonds. He carries the weight of his brother's sacrifice with quiet dignity, often lost in thought when not engaged in conversation. Despite his grief, he maintains a soldier's discipline and is respectful to those he encounters.

Private Kowalski's Backstory: Private Kowalski enlisted in the New California Republic Army several years ago, following in the footsteps of his older brother, Donald. The two siblings served together in the same unit, with Donald acting as a mentor figure to Kowalski during their early deployments. During the First Battle of Hoover Dam, their unit was pinned down by Legion forces with several wounded soldiers unable to retreat. In a selfless act, Donald Kowalski held off the enemy advance, allowing his unit to evacuate the wounded. His sacrifice was instrumental in saving lives, but cost him his own. After the battle, Private Kowalski was granted leave to return to his family in California, with a scheduled stop at the 188 Trading Post before continuing his journey home.
